\section{cleanup package}
\label{\detokenize{cleanup:cleanup-package}}\label{\detokenize{cleanup::doc}}

\subsection{Submodules}
\label{\detokenize{cleanup:submodules}}

\subsection{cleanup.delete\_test\_files module}
\label{\detokenize{cleanup:module-cleanup.delete_test_files}}\label{\detokenize{cleanup:cleanup-delete-test-files-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!cleanup.delete\_test\_files@\spxentry{cleanup.delete\_test\_files}}\index{cleanup.delete\_test\_files@\spxentry{cleanup.delete\_test\_files}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{delete\_files\_starting\_with() (in module cleanup.delete\_test\_files)@\spxentry{delete\_files\_starting\_with()}\spxextra{in module cleanup.delete\_test\_files}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{cleanup:cleanup.delete_test_files.delete_files_starting_with}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cleanup.delete\_test\_files.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{delete\_files\_starting\_with}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{prefix}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{directory}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
This module provides utility functions to delete test\sphinxhyphen{}related files from specified directories. 
It primarily supports cleanup activities post\sphinxhyphen{}testing by removing files that match a given prefix. 
This is particularly useful in scenarios where test execution generates temporary files that need to be cleaned up afterwards.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The module relies on environment variables to dynamically set the paths of directories involved in the testing processes, 
such as where downloaded files or created files during tests are stored. Users must configure these environment variables 
appropriately to ensure that the cleanup process targets the correct directories.


\subsubsection{Environment Variables:}
\label{\detokenize{cleanup:environment-variables}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The module uses the following environment variables to determine the directories for file cleanup operations:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DOWNLOAD\_DIRECTORY}}: Specifies the directory path where files downloaded during tests are stored. This path is used
by default if no other directory is specified in the cleanup function calls.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{CREATED\_FILES\_PATH}}: Specifies the directory path where files created during tests are stored. This allows for
separation of download and upload test artifacts.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Setting Environment Variables:}
\label{\detokenize{cleanup:setting-environment-variables}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To set these environment variables in your environment, follow the instructions based on your operating system:


\paragraph{For Unix/Linux/macOS:}
\label{\detokenize{cleanup:for-unix-linux-macos}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Open your terminal and use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{export}} command to set each environment variable. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{export}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nv}{DOWNLOAD\PYGZus{}DIRECTORY}\PYG{o}{=}/path/to/download/directory
\PYG{n+nb}{export}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nv}{CREATED\PYGZus{}FILES\PYGZus{}PATH}\PYG{o}{=}/path/to/created/files/directory
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
These commands can be added to your shell profile file (e.g., \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.bashrc}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.zshrc}}) to persist the variables across sessions.


\paragraph{For Windows:}
\label{\detokenize{cleanup:for-windows}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Use the System Properties dialog to set environment variables:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Open System Properties (you can search for it in the Start menu).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Go to the Advanced tab and click on Environment Variables.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Add new system variables for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DOWNLOAD\_DIRECTORY}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{CREATED\_FILES\_PATH}} with their respective paths.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Alternatively, set them temporarily in a Command Prompt window:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{set }\PYG{n}{DOWNLOAD\PYGZus{}DIRECTORY}\PYG{p}{=}\PYG{n}{C}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{\PYGZbs{}}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{\PYGZbs{}}\PYG{n}{to}\PYG{p}{\PYGZbs{}}\PYG{n}{download}\PYG{p}{\PYGZbs{}}\PYG{n}{directory}
\PYG{n+nb}{set }\PYG{n}{CREATED\PYGZus{}FILES\PYGZus{}PATH}\PYG{p}{=}\PYG{n}{C}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{\PYGZbs{}}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{\PYGZbs{}}\PYG{n}{to}\PYG{p}{\PYGZbs{}}\PYG{n}{created}\PYG{p}{\PYGZbs{}}\PYG{n}{files}\PYG{p}{\PYGZbs{}}\PYG{n}{directory}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Functions:}
\label{\detokenize{cleanup:functions}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The module contains the following function(s):
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{delete\_files\_starting\_with(prefix, directory)}}: Deletes files in the specified \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{directory}} that 
start with the given \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{prefix}}. By default, it targets the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DOWNLOAD\_DIRECTORY}}. The function prints the names of 
deleted files or indicates if no files were deleted.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Usage:}
\label{\detokenize{cleanup:usage}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To use this module, import it into your test scripts and invoke \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{delete\_files\_starting\_with}} with the appropriate 
arguments. Here’s an example that cleans up test\sphinxhyphen{}related files from both download and upload directories:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{functional\PYGZus{}testing}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{cleanup} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{delete\PYGZus{}files\PYGZus{}starting\PYGZus{}with}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{DOWNLOAD\PYGZus{}DIRECTORY}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{CREATED\PYGZus{}FILES\PYGZus{}PATH}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Delete downloaded test files}
\PYG{n}{delete\PYGZus{}files\PYGZus{}starting\PYGZus{}with}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{test\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{DOWNLOAD\PYGZus{}DIRECTORY}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Delete uploaded/created test files}
\PYG{n}{delete\PYGZus{}files\PYGZus{}starting\PYGZus{}with}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{test\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{CREATED\PYGZus{}FILES\PYGZus{}PATH}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Ensure you have set the necessary environment variables as described to correctly target the cleanup directories.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This module assumes that the specified directories exist and that the executing user has the necessary 
permissions to delete files from them.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{main() (in module cleanup.delete\_test\_files)@\spxentry{main()}\spxextra{in module cleanup.delete\_test\_files}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{cleanup:cleanup.delete_test_files.main}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cleanup.delete\_test\_files.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{main}}}{}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
The main function that executes the cleanup process.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function calls \sphinxtitleref{delete\_files\_starting\_with} for both the download directory and the directory
where created files are stored, using the prefix \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}test\_\textquotesingle{}}} to identify files targeted for deletion.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The main function is necessary because this script is intended to be executed directly, 
specifically from a setup.sh file which automates the testing process. By defining a main function, 
we ensure that the cleanup process is executed when the script is run as a standalone program. 
This is controlled by the \sphinxtitleref{if \_\_name\_\_ == “\_\_main\_\_”:} condition at the end of the script.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The main function is a common pattern in Python programming for providing a script entry point. 
It allows the script to act as either reusable modules or as standalone programs.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{Module contents}
\label{\detokenize{cleanup:module-cleanup}}\label{\detokenize{cleanup:module-contents}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!cleanup@\spxentry{cleanup}}\index{cleanup@\spxentry{cleanup}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxstepscope


\section{config package}
\label{\detokenize{config:config-package}}\label{\detokenize{config::doc}}

\subsection{Submodules}
\label{\detokenize{config:submodules}}

\subsection{config.configuration module}
\label{\detokenize{config:module-config.configuration}}\label{\detokenize{config:config-configuration-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!config.configuration@\spxentry{config.configuration}}\index{config.configuration@\spxentry{config.configuration}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This module defines configurations and locators for Selenium\sphinxhyphen{}based functional testing of the NextCloud application.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The configurations include paths, URLs, authentication details, file paths and sizes, base names and extensions for test files,
and XPath locators for various UI elements necessary for user management, file upload/download, and user session management.
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Environment Variables:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The module leverages environment variables to allow flexible configuration across different deployment environments.
Users should set the following environment variables in their testing environment before executing tests:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{BASE\_DIR}: The base directory path where created files and downloads during tests will be stored.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{CHROME\_DRIVER\_PATH}: The file system path to the ChromeDriver executable. Defaults to \sphinxtitleref{/usr/bin/chromedriver} if not set.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{TARGET\_URL}: The URL of the NextCloud instance to be tested. Example: ‘\sphinxurl{https://nextcloud.example.com}’

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{USERNAME}: The username for authenticating with the NextCloud instance. Defaults to ‘admin’.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{PASSWORD}: The password for the user. Example: ‘password123’.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{FILE\_SIZE\_MEDIUM}: Specifies the size in mega Bytes of medium files in tests. Defaults to ‘1’.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{FILE\_SIZE\_LARGE}: Specifies the size in mega Bytes of large files in tests. Defaults to ‘1’.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{TEST\_FILE\_BASE\_LARGE}: The base name for large test files. Defaults to ‘test\_large\_file’.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{TEST\_FILE\_BASE\_MEDIUM}: The base name for medium test files. Defaults to ‘test\_medium\_file’.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{EXTENSION}: The file extension for test files. Defaults to ‘.txt’.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}


\subsubsection{Setting Environment Variables}
\label{\detokenize{config:setting-environment-variables}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Environment variables can be set in various ways depending on the operating system being used. This project contains a script that sets the environment variables for you. But if you want to set them manually, follow the instructions below:


\paragraph{Unix\sphinxhyphen{}like systems (Linux/macOS)}
\label{\detokenize{config:unix-like-systems-linux-macos}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
You can export the variables in your shell before running the tests:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{export}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nv}{BASE\PYGZus{}DIR}\PYG{o}{=}/path/to/base/dir
\PYG{n+nb}{export}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nv}{CHROME\PYGZus{}DRIVER\PYGZus{}PATH}\PYG{o}{=}/path/to/chromedriver
\PYG{n+nb}{export}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nv}{TARGET\PYGZus{}URL}\PYG{o}{=}https://nextcloud.example.com
\PYG{n+nb}{export}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nv}{USERNAME}\PYG{o}{=}admin
\PYG{n+nb}{export}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nv}{PASSWORD}\PYG{o}{=}secret
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{Windows systems}
\label{\detokenize{config:windows-systems}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
You can set environment variables using the ‘set’ command in Command Prompt:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{set} \PYG{n+nv}{BASE\PYGZus{}DIR}\PYG{p}{=}C:\PYGZbs{}path\PYGZbs{}to\PYGZbs{}base\PYGZbs{}dir
\PYG{k}{set} \PYG{n+nv}{CHROME\PYGZus{}DRIVER\PYGZus{}PATH}\PYG{p}{=}C:\PYGZbs{}path\PYGZbs{}to\PYGZbs{}chromedriver.exe
\PYG{k}{set} \PYG{n+nv}{TARGET\PYGZus{}URL}\PYG{p}{=}https://nextcloud.example.com
\PYG{k}{set} \PYG{n+nv}{USERNAME}\PYG{p}{=}admin
\PYG{k}{set} \PYG{n+nv}{PASSWORD}\PYG{p}{=}secret
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{config:usage}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This module is intended to be imported and used in functional test scripts for NextCloud. The configurations and locators defined herein facilitate interaction with the NextCloud UI through Selenium WebDriver for various testing scenarios, such as user management, file operations, and session management.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Example usage in a test script:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{selenium} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{webdriver}
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{functional\PYGZus{}test\PYGZus{}config} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{config}

\PYG{n}{driver} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{webdriver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Chrome}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{config}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{CHROME\PYGZus{}DRIVER\PYGZus{}PATH}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{driver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{config}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{TARGET\PYGZus{}URL}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Ensure that the ChromeDriver version matches the version of Chrome installed on the testing system.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsubsection{XPath Locators}
\label{\detokenize{config:xpath-locators}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This module defines several XPath locators for interacting with the NextCloud UI. These locators are used to find and interact with various buttons and other UI elements. These XPaths should work fine, until major updates in the NextCloud UI occur.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{LOGIN\_BUTTON\_XPATH}: The XPath locator for the login button. Example: \sphinxtitleref{‘//input{[}@type=”submit”{]}’}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{LOGOUT\_BUTTON\_XPATH}: The XPath locator for the logout button. Example: \sphinxtitleref{‘//a{[}@id=”logout”{]}’}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{UPLOAD\_BUTTON\_XPATH}: The XPath locator for the file upload button. Example: \sphinxtitleref{‘//input{[}@type=”file”{]}’}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{DELETE\_BUTTON\_XPATH}: The XPath locator for the delete file button. Example: \sphinxtitleref{‘//a{[}@class=”action delete”{]}’}.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
These XPath locators are used in conjunction with Selenium’s \sphinxtitleref{find\_element\_by\_xpath} method to find and interact with the corresponding UI elements. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{login\PYGZus{}button} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{driver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{find\PYGZus{}element\PYGZus{}by\PYGZus{}xpath}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{config}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{LOGIN\PYGZus{}BUTTON\PYGZus{}XPATH}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{login\PYGZus{}button}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{click}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The exact XPath locators will depend on the specific structure and styling of your NextCloud instance’s UI. If the UI changes, these locators may need to be updated.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{Module contents}
\label{\detokenize{config:module-config}}\label{\detokenize{config:module-contents}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!config@\spxentry{config}}\index{config@\spxentry{config}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxstepscope


\section{file\_management\_cycle module}
\label{\detokenize{file_management_cycle:module-file_management_cycle}}\label{\detokenize{file_management_cycle:file-management-cycle-module}}\label{\detokenize{file_management_cycle::doc}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!file\_management\_cycle@\spxentry{file\_management\_cycle}}\index{file\_management\_cycle@\spxentry{file\_management\_cycle}!module@\spxentry{module}}

\subsection{Automated Test Sequence for File and User Management Functionalities}
\label{\detokenize{file_management_cycle:automated-test-sequence-for-file-and-user-management-functionalities}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This automated test script is designed to validate the comprehensive functionalities related to file and user management within a web application environment. It executes a series of operations to test the system’s ability to handle user and file lifecycle processes, such as adding and removing users, uploading, downloading, sharing files, and verifying file integrity, within a single, continuous execution flow.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This script is intended to be executed indirectly via the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{setup.sh}} shell script after all necessary environment variables have been configured. It is an example of how the test modules can be utilized in a real\sphinxhyphen{}world scenario, demonstrating the critical nature of the tested functionalities.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The test script follows a predetermined sequence of steps \sphinxtitleref{explained below} to simulate realistic application usage scenarios. The steps are encapsulated in a function.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsubsection{Execution Context}
\label{\detokenize{file_management_cycle:execution-context}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Not for Direct Execution}: This script is executed as part of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{setup.sh}} script, which prepares the environment and triggers this test sequence.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Environment Configuration}: Necessary environment variables and application settings must be configured prior to execution.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Example Usage}
\label{\detokenize{file_management_cycle:example-usage}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This script is not intended for direct call. It is automatically executed, after setting up all environment variables through \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{setup.sh}}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
./setup.sh\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+sb}{`}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}username\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+sb}{`}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+sb}{`}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}password\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+sb}{`}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} This script indirectly executes the Python test script.}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The test utilizes pytest fixtures for setting up the driver and test files.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Detailed error messages are generated for failures, facilitating quick identification and remediation of issues encountered during testing.

\end{itemize}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The stringent test sequence and its execution context highlight the script’s role in ensuring the application’s operational integrity and reliability.
\index{driver() (in module file\_management\_cycle)@\spxentry{driver()}\spxextra{in module file\_management\_cycle}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{file_management_cycle:file_management_cycle.driver}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{file\_management\_cycle.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{driver}}}{}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Pytest fixture that sets up and tears down a webdriver session.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This fixture uses the \sphinxtitleref{setup\_driver} function to initialize a webdriver session. 
The driver object is then yielded for use in other test functions.

\sphinxAtStartPar
After all tests have finished using the driver, the \sphinxtitleref{driver.quit} method is called to 
close the browser and end the webdriver session.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The fixture has a session scope, which means it’s invoked once per test session. 
The same driver object can be used across multiple test functions in the test session.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A webdriver object for interacting with the browser.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
webdriver object

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{test\_file\_management\_cycle() (in module file\_management\_cycle)@\spxentry{test\_file\_management\_cycle()}\spxextra{in module file\_management\_cycle}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{file_management_cycle:file_management_cycle.test_file_management_cycle}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{file\_management\_cycle.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{test\_file\_management\_cycle}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{driver}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{test\_files}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Test the file management cycle: upload, download, check integrity, share, delete.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function tests the entire file management cycle in a sequential manner. It includes the following steps:


\subsection{Workflow}
\label{\detokenize{file_management_cycle:workflow}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Login}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Add a User}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Upload Medium and Large Files}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Download Files}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Verify File Integrity}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Share File}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Delete Files}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Delete User}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Logout}

\end{enumerate}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If any step in this sequence fails, the entire test is considered failed and an assertion error is raised with a relevant error message. This strict pass/fail criteria ensure the application’s critical functionalities are robustly validated. The interdependency of test steps highlights the integrated nature of the application’s functionalities.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Pytest fixture that creates and returns paths and names of medium and large size test files.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This fixture uses the \sphinxtitleref{create\_testing\_files} function to create medium and large size test files. 
The paths and names of these files are then returned for use in other test functions.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The fixture has a session scope, which means it’s invoked once per test session. 
The created files can be used across multiple test functions in the test session.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A tuple containing the paths and names of the medium and large size test files. 
The tuple is structured as follows: 
(medium\_size\_file\_path, medium\_size\_file\_name, large\_size\_file\_path, large\_size\_file\_name)

\section{tests package}

\subsection{tests.end\_to\_end\_encryption module}
\label{\detokenize{tests:module-tests.end_to_end_encryption}}\label{\detokenize{tests:tests-end-to-end-encryption-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!tests.end\_to\_end\_encryption@\spxentry{tests.end\_to\_end\_encryption}}\index{tests.end\_to\_end\_encryption@\spxentry{tests.end\_to\_end\_encryption}!module@\spxentry{module}}

\subsubsection{Testing End\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}End Encryption (E2EE) in Nextcloud Client}
\label{\detokenize{tests:testing-end-to-end-encryption-e2ee-in-nextcloud-client}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This documentation provides a comprehensive guide to manually test the End\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}End Encryption (E2EE) functionality in the Nextcloud client. E2EE is designed to protect user data from access by the server or any other unauthorized entities. Due to the complexity of interacting with the GUI in a Linux environment, this test is conducted manually.


\paragraph{Prerequisites}
\label{\detokenize{tests:prerequisites}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Before proceeding with the testing, ensure the following prerequisites are met:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A functioning Nextcloud server deployment.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to a Linux environment with GUI support for installing and operating the Nextcloud client.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Administrative access to the Kubernetes cluster where Nextcloud is deployed, to verify encrypted files directly on the server.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Steps}
\label{\detokenize{tests:steps}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Install and Enable the End\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}End Encryption App}:
Before installing the Nextcloud client, ensure the End\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}End Encryption (E2EE) app is installed and enabled on your Nextcloud server. This app is crucial for securing your files during storage and transfer.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Navigate to Apps}:
Log into your Nextcloud server web interface as an administrator.

\end{itemize}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=150\sphinxpxdimen]{{navigate_to_apps}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Access the Apps Management Page}:
Click on your user profile icon at the top right corner of the interface and select ‘Apps’ from the dropdown menu.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Install the End\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}End Encryption App}:
In the Apps management page, go to the ‘Files’ category. Find the ‘End\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}End Encryption’ app in the list, and click ‘Download and enable’.

\end{itemize}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{download_e2ee}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Enable the App}:
After the download completes, the app will automatically be enabled. Verify this by checking that it appears in your list of enabled apps.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Note:}
\sphinxhyphen{} Ensure that your Nextcloud server is compatible with the version of the End\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}End Encryption app you intend to install. Compatibility details are usually listed on the app’s page within the Apps management interface.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Verify E2EE App Activation}:
\sphinxhyphen{} Confirm the activation of the End\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}End Encryption app by navigating to ‘Settings’ under your profile menu. Check the ‘Security’ section to see if the End\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}End Encryption settings are available and configured correctly.

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{verify_e2ee}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Download and Install the Nextcloud Client}:
This section outlines two methods to install the Nextcloud client on Linux: using Snap and using the APT repository. Follow the method that best suits your environment.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Using Snap:}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Update your package index and install snapd if it’s not already installed:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sudo\PYG{+w}{ }apt\PYG{+w}{ }update
sudo\PYG{+w}{ }apt\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }snapd
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Install the Nextcloud desktop client using Snap:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sudo\PYG{+w}{ }snap\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }nextcloud\PYGZhy{}desktop\PYGZhy{}client
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Using APT Repository (For Ubuntu 17.10 and later):}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Open a terminal window and add the Nextcloud PPA to your system:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sudo\PYG{+w}{ }add\PYGZhy{}apt\PYGZhy{}repository\PYG{+w}{ }ppa:nextcloud\PYGZhy{}devs/client
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Update the package index after adding the PPA:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sudo\PYG{+w}{ }apt\PYG{+w}{ }update
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Install the Nextcloud client:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sudo\PYG{+w}{ }apt\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }nextcloud\PYGZhy{}client
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Note:}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Snap method is generally simpler and provides automatic updates to the Nextcloud client.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The APT method allows for more control over the installation process and may provide a more integrated system experience depending on your specific Linux distribution.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Choose the installation method that aligns with your system management preferences and follow the corresponding steps to complete the installation.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Connect the Client to the Nextcloud Server}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Launch the Nextcloud client.

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{login}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Click on the loin button

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Enter the URL of your Nextcloud server and provide the necessary credentials to establish a connection.

\end{itemize}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{add_uri}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Accept the connection request from the server and log in to your Nextcloud account.

\end{itemize}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{accept-connection}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{grant}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Create and Encrypt a Folder}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Within the Nextcloud client, create a new folder. You can name it \sphinxtitleref{TestE2EE}.

\end{itemize}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{create_new_folder}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Inside this folder, create a new text file named \sphinxtitleref{test.txt}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Enter some content into the text file, for example, “This is a test for E2EE.”

\end{itemize}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{text}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Save the file. Then, right\sphinxhyphen{}click on the \sphinxtitleref{TestE2EE} folder and select the option to encrypt the folder.

\end{itemize}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{encrypt}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Verify the File on the Server}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access your Kubernetes cluster where Nextcloud is deployed.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Use the command line to run:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
kubectl\PYG{+w}{ }get\PYG{+w}{ }pv
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Identify the persistent volume (PV) used by Nextcloud, usually tagged as \sphinxtitleref{nextcloud\sphinxhyphen{}data}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Describe the PV to find the storage path on the node:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
kubectl\PYG{+w}{ }describe\PYG{+w}{ }pv\PYG{+w}{ }nextcloud\PYGZhy{}data
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Execute sudo \sphinxhyphen{}i and then access the server’s storage path where Nextcloud data is stored:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sudo\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}i
\PYG{n+nb}{cd}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZlt{}path\PYGZhy{}to\PYGZhy{}my\PYGZhy{}nextcloud\PYGZhy{}data\PYGZhy{}pvc\PYGZhy{}directory\PYGZgt{}/data/admin/files
\PYG{n+nb}{cd}\PYG{+w}{ }test\PYGZus{}E2EE
ls
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Navigate to the directory containing user files and attempt to read the contents of \sphinxtitleref{test.txt}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
cat\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZlt{}username\PYGZgt{}/files/\PYGZlt{}encrypted\PYG{+w}{ }file\PYG{+w}{ }name\PYGZgt{}.txt
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{itemize}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{get-describe}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{cd}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Check Encryption}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Review the output from the \sphinxtitleref{cat} command.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The contents of \sphinxtitleref{test.txt} should appear garbled or encrypted, indicating that E2EE is functioning correctly.

\end{itemize}

\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=400\sphinxpxdimen]{{encrypted_file}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}

\end{enumerate}


\paragraph{Conclusion}
\label{\detokenize{tests:conclusion}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This manual test confirms whether E2EE is effectively encrypting files as expected, preventing unauthorized access even if server storage is compromised. Due to the nature of manual testing, this process is recommended to be conducted periodically to ensure ongoing compliance and functionality of the E2EE feature in Nextcloud.


\paragraph{Note}
\label{\detokenize{tests:note}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
For automated tests or more complex scenarios, consider scripting interactions with the Nextcloud client using tools capable of GUI automation, tailored for your specific testing environment and requirements.


\subsection{tests.test\_create\_user module}
\label{\detokenize{tests:module-tests.test_create_user}}\label{\detokenize{tests:tests-test-create-user-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!tests.test\_create\_user@\spxentry{tests.test\_create\_user}}\index{tests.test\_create\_user@\spxentry{tests.test\_create\_user}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{add\_user() (in module tests.test\_create\_user)@\spxentry{add\_user()}\spxextra{in module tests.test\_create\_user}}

\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tests.test\_create\_user.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{add\_user}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{driver}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{username}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{display\_name}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{password}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{email}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{group}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{quota}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{manager}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Adds a new user to the application with specified attributes.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function utilizes the \sphinxtitleref{add\_user\_and\_check\_presence} utility function from the
\sphinxtitleref{functional\_testing.utils.user\_management} module to create a new user in the application. It then verifies
the presence of the newly added user to ensure successful creation. The process involves automating browser
interactions using Selenium WebDriver to fill and submit the new user form with provided user details.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

application’s interface.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{username}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The username for the new user. Must be unique within the application.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{display\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The display name of the new user. This is the name that will be displayed within the
application’s UI.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{password}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The password for the new user’s account. Ensure compliance with application’s password
policy.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{email}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The email address associated with the new user. Must be in a valid email format.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

Available groups may vary based on application configuration.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{quota}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{optional}}) \textendash{} The storage quota assigned to the new user’s account. Defaults to ‘1 GB’. The format
and available options may depend on application settings.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{manager}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{optional}}) \textendash{} The username of the user’s manager. Defaults to ‘admin’. This is relevant in
applications with hierarchical user management.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar

False if the addition fails at any step or if the user cannot be verified post\sphinxhyphen{}creation.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\subsection{tests.test\_delete\_user module}
\label{\detokenize{tests:module-tests.test_delete_user}}\label{\detokenize{tests:tests-test-delete-user-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!tests.test\_delete\_user@\spxentry{tests.test\_delete\_user}}\index{tests.test\_delete\_user@\spxentry{tests.test\_delete\_user}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{delete\_user() (in module tests.test\_delete\_user)@\spxentry{delete\_user()}\spxextra{in module tests.test\_delete\_user}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{tests:tests.test_delete_user.delete_user}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tests.test\_delete\_user.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{delete\_user}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{driver}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{username}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Deletes a specified user from the application and verifies their absence.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function navigates to the user management page, performs the deletion of a user based on the given username,
and checks to ensure the user is no longer present in the application. It utilizes utility functions for navigation,
user deletion, and verification of user absence. If the function encounters any exceptions during the process, it
returns False, indicating the user was not successfully deleted.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{driver}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{WebDriver}}) \textendash{} An instance of Selenium WebDriver, used to automate browser interactions.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{username}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The username of the user to be deleted. This is used to identify the specific user in the 
user management interface.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns True if the user is successfully deleted and confirmed to be absent from the application.
Returns False if the deletion process fails at any step or if the user is still present after the
deletion attempt.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
bool

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{Exception}} \textendash{} Propagates any exceptions encountered during navigation, user deletion, or verification
of user absence. It logs the exception before re\sphinxhyphen{}raising, providing context for the error.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The function assumes that it’s being called within the context of an authenticated session where
the driver has access to the application’s user management interface.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This function relies on external utility functions \sphinxtitleref{navigate\_to\_users\_page}, \sphinxtitleref{perform\_delete\_user},
and \sphinxtitleref{check\_user\_absence} for various steps of the process. Ensure these are correctly implemented
and accessible in the project.

\end{itemize}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Deletes a specified file from NextCloud.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function navigates to the NextCloud files section by ensuring the session is logged in. It then attempts to
delete a file with the given name. Successful deletion is verified internally by the function \sphinxtitleref{perform\_delete\_file}.
If the deletion process encounters any issues, an exception is raised.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{driver}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{WebDriver}}) \textendash{} An instance of Selenium WebDriver used for automating interactions with the NextCloud web
application. It should be properly initialized and configured prior to calling this function.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{file\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The name of the file to be deleted from NextCloud. The name should match exactly with the file
present in NextCloud, including file extension.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
True if the file is successfully deleted, False otherwise. This adjustment from the original docstring
without a return statement provides clarity on the function’s success through a boolean.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
bool

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{AssertionError}} \textendash{} If the file was not deleted successfully. This assertion could be raised within the
\sphinxtitleref{perform\_delete\_file} function based on the verification of the file’s absence after the
deletion attempt. Handling or logging this error in the calling context is recommended to
make informed workflow decisions based on the file deletion success.

\subsection{tests.test\_file\_download module}

\pysigstartsignatures

\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Downloads a specified file from NextCloud.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function first ensures that the session is logged into NextCloud, and that the file management screen is open, by invoking \sphinxtitleref{ensure\_logged\_in\_and\_goto\_files}.
It then attempts to download a file with the specified \sphinxtitleref{file\_name}. The success of the download operation is
determined by checking the presence of the downloaded file in a predetermined download directory. This function
assumes that \sphinxtitleref{perform\_download\_file} is responsible for both downloading the file and verifying its presence
in the \sphinxtitleref{DOWNLOAD\_DIRECTORY}.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{driver}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{WebDriver}}) \textendash{} An instance of Selenium WebDriver, used for automating interactions with the web
application. The driver should be configured to handle file downloads, including
specifying the download directory.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{file\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The name of the file to be downloaded from NextCloud. The file name should include any
file extension if applicable and match exactly with a file available in NextCloud.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
True if the file is successfully downloaded and verified to be present in the local download
directory, False otherwise.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
bool

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{Exception}} \textendash{} If any error occurs during the process of navigating to the files page, initiating the file
download, or verifying the file’s presence in the local directory.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The function leverages configuration variables from \sphinxtitleref{functional\_testing.config.configuration} for navigation
and login.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The download directory is set via the \sphinxtitleref{DOWNLOAD\_DIRECTORY} configuration variable. This directory should
be correctly configured in both the WebDriver setup and the environment to ensure downloaded files are
saved and found as expected.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The function prints a success message in green upon successful download. This visual cue can be helpful in
interactive or manual testing scenarios.

\end{itemize}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\subsection{tests.test\_file\_integrity module}
\label{\detokenize{tests:module-tests.test_file_integrity}}\label{\detokenize{tests:tests-test-file-integrity-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!tests.test\_file\_integrity@\spxentry{tests.test\_file\_integrity}}\index{tests.test\_file\_integrity@\spxentry{tests.test\_file\_integrity}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{file\_integrity() (in module tests.test\_file\_integrity)@\spxentry{file\_integrity()}\spxextra{in module tests.test\_file\_integrity}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{tests:tests.test_file_integrity.file_integrity}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tests.test\_file\_integrity.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{file\_integrity}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{file\_name}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Verifies the integrity of a file by comparing the hash of the uploaded file with that of the downloaded file.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function aims to ensure data integrity by verifying that a file, once uploaded and then downloaded from
NextCloud, remains unaltered. It computes and compares the hash values of both the uploaded and downloaded
versions of the file located in predetermined directories. A match in hash values indicates that the file has
maintained its integrity throughout the upload and download process.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{file\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The name of the file for which integrity is being checked. This name should include any
file extension and match exactly between the uploaded and downloaded files.

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns True if the hash values of the uploaded and downloaded files match, indicating the files are
identical and integrity is preserved. Returns False if there is a mismatch in hash values, suggesting
the files are different and integrity may have been compromised.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
bool

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{AssertionError}} \textendash{} Raises an assertion error if the hash comparison fails, indicating the uploaded and
downloaded files are not the same. This may point to issues in the file transfer process
or unauthorized alterations of the file content.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Example}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{example\PYGZus{}document.pdf}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{integrity\PYGZus{}check} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}integrity}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{integrity\PYGZus{}check}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{File integrity verified.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{File integrity compromised.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The function relies on the \sphinxtitleref{compare\_hashes} utility to perform the hash computation and comparison. Ensure
that \sphinxtitleref{DOWNLOAD\_DIRECTORY} and \sphinxtitleref{CREATED\_FILES\_PATH} in the configuration module accurately reflect the
paths to where the NextCloud application stores downloaded files and where uploaded files are kept,
respectively. It assumes that the upload and the download have been performed successfully.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{tests.test\_file\_share module}
\label{\detokenize{tests:module-tests.test_file_share}}\label{\detokenize{tests:tests-test-file-share-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!tests.test\_file\_share@\spxentry{tests.test\_file\_share}}\index{tests.test\_file\_share@\spxentry{tests.test\_file\_share}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{locate\_and\_click\_share\_button() (in module tests.test\_file\_share)@\spxentry{locate\_and\_click\_share\_button()}\spxextra{in module tests.test\_file\_share}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{tests:tests.test_file_share.locate_and_click_share_button}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tests.test\_file\_share.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{locate\_and\_click\_share\_button}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{driver}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{file\_name}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Shares a specified file internally and externally within NextCloud.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function handles multiple steps to share a file stored in NextCloud. Initially, it navigates
to the files management page, locates the desired file, and then initiates the sharing process. It performs both
internal sharing with a specified recipient and generates external sharing links. The function also validates 
the accessibility of these shared links by simulating external access to ensure that the sharing functionality 
works as expected.
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Args:}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{driver (WebDriver): An instance of Selenium WebDriver used for automating browser interactions. It must be}
\sphinxAtStartPar
initialized and configured before being passed to this function.

\sphinxlineitem{username (str): The username of the recipient with whom the file will be shared internally. This user must}
\sphinxAtStartPar
exist within the NextCloud system.

\sphinxlineitem{password (str): The password for the above username, used to validate internal sharing functionality by}
\sphinxAtStartPar
attempting to access the shared file.

\sphinxlineitem{file\_name (str): The name of the file to be shared. The file should already exist in the NextCloud directory}
\sphinxAtStartPar
that the initiating user has access to.

\end{description}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns:}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{bool: True if both internal and external sharing links are generated and validated successfully, indicating}
\sphinxAtStartPar
that the file has been shared properly. Returns False if any step in the sharing or validation process
fails.

\end{description}

\sphinxlineitem{Raises:}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Exception: If an error occurs at any point during the file sharing process, including issues with locating}
\sphinxAtStartPar
the file, sharing operations, link generation, or access validations. The specific error message
is printed to the console.

\end{description}

\sphinxlineitem{Example:}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{selenium} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{webdriver}

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{password} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{password123}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{document.pdf}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{share\PYGZus{}success} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{share\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{driver}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{username}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{password}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{File shared successfully.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{File sharing failed.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxlineitem{Note:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This function assumes that the user initiating the share (typically an admin or the file owner) is
logged into NextCloud at the start of the function.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The function performs a logout operation as part of its external link validation step, and then logs
back in as the admin user. Ensure that any necessary session data is saved or that subsequent operations
account for this logout/login cycle.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{selenium} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{webdriver}

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{document.pdf}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}

\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This function assumes that the user initiating the share (typically an admin or the file owner) is
logged into NextCloud at the start of the function.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The function performs a logout operation as part of its external link validation step, and then logs
back in as the admin user. Ensure that any necessary session data is saved or that subsequent operations
account for this logout/login cycle.

\end{itemize}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{tests.test\_file\_upload module}
\label{\detokenize{tests:module-tests.test_file_upload}}\label{\detokenize{tests:tests-test-file-upload-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!tests.test\_file\_upload@\spxentry{tests.test\_file\_upload}}\index{tests.test\_file\_upload@\spxentry{tests.test\_file\_upload}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{upload\_file() (in module tests.test\_file\_upload)@\spxentry{upload\_file()}\spxextra{in module tests.test\_file\_upload}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{tests:tests.test_file_upload.upload_file}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tests.test\_file\_upload.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{upload\_file}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{driver}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{file\_path}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Uploads a file to NextCloud and verifies its presence in the file list in Nextcloud UI.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function automates the process of uploading a file to NextCloud using Selenium WebDriver. It ensures that
the user is logged in and navigates to the files section. The function then initiates the file upload process and
verifies whether the uploaded file appears in NextCloud’s file list. If the file is not found within a specified
timeout, the upload is considered unsuccessful.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{driver}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{WebDriver}}) \textendash{} The Selenium WebDriver instance used to automate browser interactions. It should be
initialized and configured to the target NextCloud instance prior to calling this function.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{file\_path}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The absolute path of the file on the local system that is to be uploaded. Ensure that the
path is accessible and readable by the script to avoid errors during the upload process.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
True if the file is successfully uploaded and verified to be present in NextCloud’s file list.
False if the file does not appear in the list after the upload process, indicating a failure.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
bool

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{Exception}} \textendash{} General exception if an error occurs at any point during the login, navigation, upload process,
or file presence check. The specific exception message is printed to provide insights into the
failure reason.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This function assumes that \sphinxtitleref{TARGET\_URL}, \sphinxtitleref{USERNAME}, \sphinxtitleref{PASSWORD}, \sphinxtitleref{LOGIN\_BUTTON\_XPATH}, \sphinxtitleref{FILES\_TAB\_XPATH},
\sphinxtitleref{NEW\_FILE\_OR\_FOLDER\_MENU\_XPATH}, and \sphinxtitleref{FILE\_UPLOAD\_START\_ID} are correctly configured in the
\sphinxtitleref{functional\_testing.config.configuration} module.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Ensure that the WebDriver instance (\sphinxtitleref{driver}) has been correctly authenticated with NextCloud prior to
calling this function if not relying on the function’s login mechanism. It’s recommended to use the login function before calling this function.

\end{itemize}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{selenium} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{webdriver}
\PYG{n}{driver} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{webdriver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Chrome}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}path} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{/path/to/your/file.txt}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{upload\PYGZus{}success} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{upload\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{driver}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{upload\PYGZus{}success}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{File upload successful.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{File upload failed.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{tests.test\_login module}
\label{\detokenize{tests:module-tests.test_login}}\label{\detokenize{tests:tests-test-login-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!tests.test\_login@\spxentry{tests.test\_login}}\index{tests.test\_login@\spxentry{tests.test\_login}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{login() (in module tests.test\_login)@\spxentry{login()}\spxextra{in module tests.test\_login}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{tests:tests.test_login.login}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tests.test\_login.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{login}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{driver}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Authenticates a user into NextCloud using predefined credentials.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function orchestrates the process of logging into a NextCloud instance. It begins by navigating to the 
NextCloud login page, specified by \sphinxtitleref{TARGET\_URL}, and then proceeds to input the predefined credentials 
(\sphinxtitleref{USERNAME} and \sphinxtitleref{PASSWORD}) into the login form. The function checks for successful authentication by verifying 
the presence of elements unique to authenticated sessions. If the login attempt faces any issues, the function 
gracefully handles exceptions and provides feedback.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{driver}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{WebDriver}}) \textendash{} An instance of a Selenium WebDriver, used to automate web browser interaction.
The driver must be initialized and configured prior to calling this function.

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Indicates the outcome of the login attempt. Returns True if the login process completes successfully, 
indicating that the user has been authenticated. Returns False if there are any issues during the 
login process, suggesting that the authentication did not occur.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
bool

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{Exception}} \textendash{} Raises a generic exception if any unexpected errors occur during the execution of the login 
process. The exception captures and suppresses detailed error information to prevent potential 
sensitive data exposure, adhering to security best practices.

\sphinxlineitem{Example}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{selenium} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{webdriver}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{driver} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{webdriver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Chrome}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{login\PYGZus{}success} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{login}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{driver}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{login\PYGZus{}success}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Login successful.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Login failed.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxlineitem{Note}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The login process relies on several configuration variables defined in the 
\sphinxtitleref{functional\_testing.config.configuration} module, including \sphinxtitleref{TARGET\_URL}, \sphinxtitleref{USERNAME}, \sphinxtitleref{PASSWORD}, and 
\sphinxtitleref{LOGIN\_BUTTON\_XPATH}. Ensure these variables are accurately set to reflect the current state of the 
NextCloud login page and user credentials.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{tests.test\_logout module}
\label{\detokenize{tests:module-tests.test_logout}}\label{\detokenize{tests:tests-test-logout-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!tests.test\_logout@\spxentry{tests.test\_logout}}\index{tests.test\_logout@\spxentry{tests.test\_logout}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{logout() (in module tests.test\_logout)@\spxentry{logout()}\spxextra{in module tests.test\_logout}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{tests:tests.test_logout.logout}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tests.test\_logout.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{logout}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{driver}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Performs logout from the application using the provided WebDriver instance.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function navigates the application’s UI to log out the currently authenticated user. It specifically
handles the UI interactions required to open the settings menu, click the logout button, and verify the logout
process by checking for the presence of the login button. It uses a series of utility functions tailored to
interact with specific UI elements defined in the configuration module.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{driver}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{WebDriver}}) \textendash{} An instance of Selenium WebDriver. This is used to automate the interaction with
the web browser, enabling the function to perform actions like clicking and checking
the presence of UI elements.

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Indicates the outcome of the logout attempt. Returns True if the logout process is completed
successfully, evidenced by the appearance of the login button. Returns False if the logout
process fails at any step, either due to UI elements not being found or other exceptions.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
bool

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{NoSuchElementException}} \textendash{} Raised if any expected UI element involved in the logout process is not found
within the current page. This exception points to possible changes in the UI or
an incorrect navigation state.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{Exception}} \textendash{} A generic exception is raised for any other errors encountered during the logout process.
The function catches and logs these exceptions, providing a message detailing the encountered
issue.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{Example}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{driver} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{webdriver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Chrome}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{logout\PYGZus{}success} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{logout}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{driver}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{logout\PYGZus{}success}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Successfully logged out.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Logout failed.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The function assumes that the user is already logged in and that the WebDriver instance (\sphinxtitleref{driver}) is in a
state that allows direct interaction with the application’s logout functionality. It relies on accurate
XPath locators for the settings menu and logout button, specified in \sphinxtitleref{OPEN\_SETTINGS\_MENU\_XPATH}, 
\sphinxtitleref{CLOSED\_SETTINGS\_MENU\_XPATH}, and \sphinxtitleref{LOGOUT\_BUTTON\_PATH}, which should be configured in the
\sphinxtitleref{functional\_testing.config.configuration} module before invoking this function.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\sphinxAtStartPar

\end{description}

\subsection{utils.user\_management module}
\label{\detokenize{utils:module-utils.user_management}}\label{\detokenize{utils:utils-user-management-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!utils.user\_management@\spxentry{utils.user\_management}}\index{utils.user\_management@\spxentry{utils.user\_management}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{add\_user\_and\_check\_presence() (in module utils.user\_management)@\spxentry{add\_user\_and\_check\_presence()}\spxextra{in module utils.user\_management}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{utils:utils.user_management.add_user_and_check_presence}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{utils.user\_management.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{add\_user\_and\_check\_presence}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{driver}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{username}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{display\_name}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{password}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{email}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{group}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{quota}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{manager}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{NEW\_USER\_BUTTONS\_XPATH}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Adds a user to the application and verifies their presence in the user list.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function navigates the application’s UI to add a new user with provided details.
After adding, it attempts to locate the user in the application’s user list to verify
successful addition. If the user is found, the operation is considered successful.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{driver}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{WebDriver}}) \textendash{} WebDriver instance for interacting with the web application.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{username}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The username of the new user.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{display\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The display name of the new user.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{password}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The password for the new user.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{email}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The email address of the new user.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{group}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The group to which the new user belongs.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{quota}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The quota assigned to the new user.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{manager}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The manager of the new user.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{NEW\_USER\_BUTTONS\_XPATH}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{dict}}) \textendash{} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A collection of keyword arguments mapping descriptive
names to XPaths. These XPaths are used to interact with various UI elements
necessary for user creation. Expected keys include:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
OPEN\_SETTINGS\_MENU\_XPATH: XPath to open the settings menu.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
USERS\_BUTTON\_XPATH: XPath to access the users section.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
NEW\_USER\_BUTTON: XPath to initiate new user creation.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
NEW\_USERNAME\_INPUT: XPath for entering the user’s username.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
NEW\_USER\_ADD\_BUTTON: XPath to finalize adding the new user.

\end{itemize}


\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
True if the user is successfully added and found in the user list; returns False otherwise.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
bool

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{Exception}} \textendash{} Raises an exception if there’s an issue during the user addition process
or while checking the user’s presence.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{fill\_user\_form() (in module utils.user\_management)@\spxentry{fill\_user\_form()}\spxextra{in module utils.user\_management}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{utils:utils.user_management.fill_user_form}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{utils.user\_management.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{fill\_user\_form}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{driver}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{username}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{display\_name}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{password}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{email}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{group}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{quota}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{manager}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{NEW\_USER\_BUTTONS\_XPATH}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Fills the user form with provided details in a NextCloud application.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function automates the process of filling out the user creation form in the NextCloud UI. 
It inputs the provided user details into the form fields, selects the specified user group, and sets the user quota. 
The function relies on a dictionary of XPaths to various form elements to interact with them.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{driver}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{WebDriver}}) \textendash{} The Selenium WebDriver instance used for browser automation.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{username}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} Username to be entered in the form.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{display\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} Display name to be entered in the form.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{password}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} Password to be entered in the form.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{email}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} Email address to be entered in the form.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{group}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} User group to be selected from a dropdown.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{quota}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} User data quota to be entered in the form.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{manager}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} Manager’s name to be entered in the form.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{NEW\_USER\_BUTTONS\_XPATH}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{dict}}) \textendash{} A dictionary mapping descriptive names to XPaths for interacting with the form.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Indicates whether the user form was successfully filled.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
bool

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{Exception}} \textendash{} If an error occurs while filling the user form, providing the encountered error message.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
